Despite this tadlis classification, he remains acceptable due to his overall reliability.

hadiths.english_translation: It is reported that al-Hakam ibn Utaybah had the kunya (patronymic) Abu Abdullah. Muhammad ibn Sa'd also reported: I walked with Abdullah ibn Idris on an errand, and when we reached the Shahar Suj area of Kindah, he stopped me at the door of a house and said: Do you know whose house this is? This is the house of al-Hakam ibn Utaybah, and he was a freed slave of Kindah, and al-Hakam and Ibrahim al-Nakha'i were of the same age, born in the same year.

hadiths.english_translation: I saw al-Hakam with a white beard. [Second chain] Al-Hakam used to wrap a Sabrion turban and led prayer in a single robe. When I asked him about it, he said: If a man from the companions of the Prophet ﷺ used to pray or lead prayer in a single robe with nothing else upon him.

hadiths.english_translation: Al-Hakam died in Kufa in the year 115 AH, during the caliphate of Hisham ibn Abd al-Malik. Ibn Idris said: In that same year I was born. And al-Hakam ibn Utaybah was trustworthy, learned, elevated, eminent, and transmitted many hadiths.

hadiths.english_translation: When Ibrahim died, we thought al-A'mash would be his successor, so we came to him and asked him about permissible and forbidden things, but he knew nothing. Then we asked him about inheritance laws (al-Fara'id), and he knew them well. Then we came to Hammad and asked him about inheritance laws, but he knew nothing. Then we asked him about permissible and forbidden things, and he was its master. So we took inheritance laws from al-A'mash and permissible and forbidden matters from Hammad, from Ibrahim. [Second chain:] I saw Hammad praying in a yellow lower garment and a red wrap.

hadiths.english_translation: I heard my mother, the daughter of Ismail ibn Hammad ibn Abi Sulayman, saying: I sometimes saw the Quran in the lap of my grandfather Hammad ibn Abi Sulayman, with tears on its pages. They (the scholars) all agreed that Hammad ibn Abi Sulayman died in the year 120 AH during the caliphate of Hisham ibn Abd al-Malik. He came to Basra to visit Bilal ibn Abi Burdah, who was its governor, and from him Hisham al-Dustua'i, Hammad ibn Salamah, and others heard narrations on that visit. Hammad ibn Zayd said: Ayyub did not come to him, so we did not come to him, and we would not come to anyone whom Ayyub did not visit. When Hammad returned to Kufa, they asked him: How did you find the people of Basra? He said: A group of the people of the Levant who settled among us, meaning they are not like us regarding the matter of Ali. They said: Hammad was weak in hadith, became confused in his later life, was a Murji'i (believer in deferring judgment), and transmitted many hadiths.

narrators.name: Malik ibn Ismail
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Ismail ibn Hamad al-Kufi Abu Ismail

This entry contains numerous anecdotes from various sources (Ibn Zayd's account, collective scholarly opinion) woven into one biographical narrative.

hadiths.english_translation: Al-Harith al-Uklii and Ibn Shubramah used to discuss judicial matters after the Isha prayer (night prayer). Abu al-Mughirah used to pass by them and say: Is what you are doing during the day not enough for you, until you also discuss it at this hour? And he was trustworthy, transmitting few hadiths.

narrators.name: Hushaym
narrators.full_name: Hushaym ibn Bashir al-Sulami Abu Muhammad

narrators.name: al-Mughirah
narrators.full_name: al-Mughirah ibn Miqsam al-Kufi

narrators.name: al-Harith al-Uklii
narrators.full_name: al-Harith al-Uklii

chainIssues: Uses indirect transmission term 'I was informed about' from Hushaym
Al-Mughirah uses direct term (أَخْبَرَنَا)
This is a biographical anecdote about scholarly dedication to jurisprudence

potential_issues.issue: Indirect transmission term at the beginning
potential_issues.impact: The use of 'I was informed about' (أُخْبِرْتُ عَنْ) instead of a more direct term creates potential for indirectness, though Hushaym is generally reliable (Saduq).
This entry records a personal observation about al-Harith al-Uklii and Ibn Shubramah's scholarly dedication to judicial matters.
The entry includes an evaluation that al-Harith was trustworthy but transmitted few hadiths, which is biographical commentary.

hadiths.IISGrade: Acceptable
Topics: Scholarly dedication of al-Harith al-Uklii to judicial study
Intensive study sessions after Isha prayer
Evaluation of al-Harith al-Uklii's reliability and hadith transmission

hadiths.english_translation: Abd al-Rahman ibn Mahdi said: I narrated to Sufyan a hadith from Abd al-A'la, and he said: We used to think it was from a book. Abd al-A'la used to narrate from Ibn al-Hanafiyyah, from Ali, frequently. Sufyan said: We used to think it was from a book, and he was weak in hadith transmission.

narrators.name: Abd al-Rahman ibn Mahdi
narrators.full_name: Abd al-Rahman ibn Mahdi ibn Abdullah al-Hamdani Abu Hatim

narrators.name: Sufyan al-Thawri
narrators.full_name: Sufyan ibn Sa'id ibn Masruq al-Thawri

narrators.name: Abd al-A'la
narrators.full_name: Abd al-A'la ibn Amir al-Tha'labi

chainIssues: Chain ends at Abd al-A'la level (maqtu')
Abd al-A'la is explicitly evaluated as weak in hadith transmission by Sufyan al-Thawri
The content suggests Abd al-A'la's hadiths may have been copied or fabricated (from a book)

potential_issues.issue: Abd al-A'la is explicitly graded as weak in hadith
potential_issues.impact: Sufyan al-Thawri, a highly reliable scholar, explicitly states that Abd al-A'la was weak in hadith transmission and that his narrations were suspected of being copied from books.
The observation that narrations were 'from a book' suggests concern about authenticity and originality of transmission.
This entry documents the assessment of Abd al-A'la's reliability by contemporary scholars.

hadiths.IISGrade: Problematic
Topics: Critical evaluation of Abd al-A'la's hadith transmission
Concern about authenticity of narrations in early Islamic hadith scholarship

hadiths.english_translation: A freed slave of Khalid ibn Khalid ibn Umarah ibn al-Walid ibn Uqbah ibn Abi Mu'it. This is how Sufyan al-Thawri used to mention him when narrating from him, as Mu'ammal ibn Ismail told me. He is Yahya ibn Adam, the hadith scholar who was in Kufa. Khalid ibn Khalid was a noble, generous, and honorable man.

narrators.name: Mu'ammal ibn Ismail
narrators.full_name: Mu'ammal ibn Ismail al-Kufi Abu Abdullah

narrators.name: Sufyan al-Thawri
narrators.full_name: Sufyan ibn Sa'id ibn Masruq al-Thawri

narrators.name: Yahya ibn Adam
narrators.full_name: Yahya ibn Adam ibn Sulayman al-Qurashi al-Kufi Abu Zakariyyah
narrators.alternative_names: Yahya ibn Adam, a hadith scholar

chainIssues: Chain records identification and characterization of Yahya ibn Adam
Biographical note about Khalid ibn Khalid's identity and qualities

potential_issues.impact: This entry provides complex lineage information and identifies that the mawla of Khalid ibn Khalid is actually Yahya ibn Adam, the well-known hadith scholar.
The entry includes evaluative descriptions of Khalid ibn Khalid as noble, generous, and honorable.

hadiths.IISGrade: Acceptable

hadiths.english_translation: My father died on the way to Mecca, and Talhah ibn Musarrif came to console us and said: It is said that three (deeds): whoever dies while finishing one of them enters Paradise: pilgrimage, or umrah, or military expedition.

narrators.name: Sulayman ibn Harb
narrators.full_name: Sulayman ibn Harb ibn Abdu al-Malik al-Thaqafi Abu Muhammad

narrators.name: Hammad ibn Zayd
narrators.full_name: Hammad ibn Zayd ibn Dinar al-Azdi Abu Ismail

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn Juhidah
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Juhidah

narrators.name: Talhah ibn Musarrif
narrators.full_name: Talhah ibn Musarrif al-Azdi

chainIssues: Uses strong transmission terms throughout (أَخْبَرَنَا and حَدَّثَنَا)
Chain ends at Talhah ibn Musarrif level (maqtu')
This is a sayings-based narration (attributed to 'it is said')

potential_issues.impact: The chain uses direct and strong transmission terms (أَخْبَرَنَا and حَدَّثَنَا) throughout, indicating reliable transmission of the biographical anecdote.
The content ('it is said that...') reflects a transmitted saying rather than a direct statement from the Prophet ﷺ, making it a maqtu' hadith.
This entry contains religious guidance about reward for death during pilgrimage, umrah, or military campaign, presented as a saying in Islamic tradition.

hadiths.IISGrade: Acceptable
Topics: Death during pilgrimage (Hajj)
Death during umrah
Death during military expedition
Reward for dying while performing acts of worship
Paradise entrance for those who die completing religious obligations
